definition:
Let $X$ be a set and let
$$X^m := \underbrace{X \times \cdots \times X}_{m-\text{times}} .$$
Denote an element of $X^m$ by $x = (x_1,\ldots,x_m).$ Define an
equivalence relation by $x \sim x'$ if and only if there exists a
permutation $\sigma$ of $(1,\ldots,m),$ such that
$x_i = x'_{\sigma{i}}$.

The $m^{\text{th}}$ symmetric power of $X$ is the set
$X^m_{sym} := X^m / \sim.$ That is, the set of equivalence classes of
$X^m$ under the relation $\sim.$

Let $\pi$ be the natural projection of $X^m$ onto $X^m_{sym}$.

$f \colon X^m \to Y$ is a symmetric function if and only if there exists
a function $g \colon X^m_{sym} \to Y$ such that $f = g \circ \pi.$

From now on let $R$ be an integral domain. Let
$\tau' \colon X^m \to X^m$ be the map
$\tau'(x) := (\tau_1(x),\ldots,\tau_m(x)),$ where $\tau_k$ is the
$k^\text{th}$ elementary symmetric polynomial. By the above lemma, we
have a function $\tau \colon X^m_{sym} \to X^m$, where
$\tau' = \tau \circ \pi .$

$\tau$ is one to one. If $R$ is algebraically closed, then $\tau$ is
onto.

A very useful case is when $R = \mathbb{C}.$ In this case, when we put
on the natural complex manifold structure onto ${\mathbb{C}}^m_{sym},$
the map $\tau$ is a biholomorphism of ${\mathbb{C}}^m_{sym}$ and
${\mathbb{C}}^m .$

[9]{} Hassler Whitney. [**]{}. Addison-Wesley, Philippines, 1972.
